The level of the bad person and the leve: The bad person is ungrateful and thankless, for the wicked only know how to be ungrateful and thankless.
The good person is grateful and thankful, for the virtuous only know how to be grateful and thankful.
Actions that would not be enough to repa: Carrying your mother around on one shoulder and your father on the other for a hundred years, and anointing, massaging, bathing, and rubbing them, even if they were to defecate and urinate right there.
Establishing your mother and father as supreme monarchs of this great earth, abounding in the seven treasures.
Actions that would be enough to repay on: Settling unethical parents in ethical conduct
Types of conduct that the Buddha teaches: Inaction regarding the many kinds of unskillful things
Action regarding the many kinds of skillful things
The brahmin's statement [an2.34:1.0]: The brahmin asks the Buddha what he teaches
The Buddha responds that he teaches action and inaction
The brahmin asks how the Buddha teaches action and inaction
The Buddha explains how he teaches action and inaction
The brahmin praises the Buddha and becomes his lay follower.
Attributes of the trainee and the master: They are worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods
The field for sponsors of sacrifice [an2: The trainee and the master are worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods
They are upright in body, speech, and mind
This is the field for sponsors of sacrifice
What's given here is very fruitful.
The person fettered internally and exter: A mendicant who is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and seeking alms in suitable places
Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken
When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in one of the orders of gods
When they pass away from there, they’re a returner, who comes back to this state of existence (person fettered internally)
They enter and remain in a certain peaceful state of freed mind
When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in one of the orders of gods
When they pass away from there, they’re a non-returner, not coming back to this state of existence (person fettered externally)
The practice of a mendicant (a causal se: They keep the rules they’ve undertaken
They practice for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding sensual pleasures
They practice for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding future lives
They practice for the ending of craving
They practice for the ending of greed
When their body breaks up, after death, they are reborn in one of the orders of gods
When they pass away from there, they are non-returners, not coming back to this state of existence (person fettered externally)
Reasons for fights among different group: Aristocrats fight with aristocrats because of their insistence on sensual desire, their shackles, avarice, and attachment.
Brahmins fight with brahmins because of their insistence on sensual desire, their shackles, avarice, and attachment.
Householders fight with householders because of their insistence on sensual desire, their shackles, avarice, and attachment.
Ascetics fight with ascetics because of their insistence on views, their shackles, avarice, and attachment.
The Blessed One who has gone beyond the: The Blessed One who is staying in the city of Sāvatthī
Homage to the Blessed One [an2.37:1.0]: Homage to that Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!
Homage to that Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!
Homage to that Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!
The consequences of strong bandits and w: The king is not at ease when going out or coming back or when touring the provinces
The brahmins and householders are not at ease when going out or coming back, or when inspecting their business activities
The good-hearted mendicants continually adhere to silence in the midst of the Saṅgha, or they stay in the borderlands
This is for the hurt and unhappiness of the people, for the harm, hurt, and suffering of many people, of gods and humans
The consequences of strong kings and wea: The king is at ease when going out or coming back or when inspecting the provinces
The brahmins and householders are at ease when going out or coming back, or when inspecting their business activities
The bad mendicants continually adhere to silence in the midst of the Saṅgha, or they leave for some place or other
This is for the welfare and happiness of the people, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.
The consequences of memorizing the disco: Taking only a semblance of the phrasing
Shutting out the meaning and the teaching
Acting for the hurt and unhappiness of the people
Not taking only a semblance of the phrasing
Reinforcing the meaning and the teaching
Acting for the welfare and happiness of the people
